title: Is the money from your personal IRA safe from creditors and student loan?
question: I owe around $50K in student loan; $10K in summary judgment; $25K in unsecured debt. I can't find a job so I want to withdraw from my IRA for everyday expenses. I am afraid the above mentioned creditors will take the money from my checking account. Is my retirement savings "protected" from above mentioned creditors? I have defaulted on my student loan and unsecured debt and haven't made any payments for the summary judgment.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Unsecured debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Estates,Inherited Roth IRA and estate planning,Taxes and estate planning,Lawsuits and disputes,Sued for debt,Tax law,Default judgment
answers:
You need to think hard and long on this issue. IRAs are not automatically exempt from judgment enforcement activities - there is a process to determine whether those funds have only been used for retirement purposes and whether or not they will be needed for retirement purposes at the time you retire. The burden of proof at this hearing is on the claimant - YOU. Bankruptcy does not get you out of the student loan debts as they are non-dischargeable in BK. So you need to figure this out with some serious financial planning.

Your IRA is safe. If you are concerned about money in your checking account, do not wait around and see if they seize it. Withdraw the money in your checking account. Regarding your 401k, you can likely access those funds if by taking a loan against the funds. If you borrow funds against your 401k there should not be a tax consequence. Based on the facts you have stated, a Chapter 7 may be a viable solution, but there are other factors to consider, to make sure you do not put any other property at risk. You should consult an attorney.

Agreed taking an IRA withdraw early is a tax issue. In bankruptcy it is almost certainly fully exempt from the trustee or creditors. You should be considering bankruptcy and a Chapter 7 to get rid of your unsecured debts, and then work on your student loans. The student loans are not a dischargeable debt in a Chapter 7 filing. If you convert money from the IRA to regular money not only will you pay tax on it if you ineligible for the withdraw and pay the penalty but you are changing the character of funds and creditors may be able to go after it.

What do you mean by "summary judgment." Is this a civil, default judgment?

If you take money from your IRA, you will owe taxes, and penalties, to the IRS. The IRS can cause you more problems than ordinary creditors or student loans.
